The [[Załuski Library]], the first public library in Poland, was founded by two brothers, [[Józef Andrzej Załuski]], crown referendary and bishop of Kiev, and [[Andrzej Stanisław Załuski]], crown chancellor and bishop of Cracow. The library was considered one of the most important libraries of the world, featuring a collection of about 400,000 printed items, manuscripts, artworks, scientific instruments, and plant and animal specimens. Located in Warsaw's [[Daniłowiczowski Palace]], it was looted in the aftermath of the [[second Partition of Poland]] and [[Kościuszko Uprising]] in 1794 by [[Russia]]n troops on orders from Russian Tsarina [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II]]; the stolen artworks were transported to [[St. Petersburg]] and became part of the [[Russian Imperial Library]], which was founded one year later. Although some pieces were returned by the [[Soviet Union]] in 1921 and were burned during the [[Warsaw Uprising]] against German forces, other parts of the collection have still not been returned by Russia. Polish scientists have been allowed to access and study the objects.<ref>[http://www.warsawvoice.pl/archiwum.phtml/7723/ What's On. Library Anniversary]. [[The Warsaw Voice]]. August 18, 1997.</ref>
The [[Polish Crown Jewels]] were removed by the [[Prussia]]ns in 1795 after the [[Partitions of Poland|Third Partition]] of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wawel.krakow.pl/en/index.php?op=8,1,5 |title = Crown Treasury |work = wawel.krakow.pl |accessdate = 2008-03-03}}</ref>
After the collapse of the [[November Uprising]], literary and art treasures were removed from Poland.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cartage.org.lb/en/themes/geoghist/histories/history/hiscountries/P/poland.html |title = Poland |work = cartage.org.lb |accessdate = 2008-03-03}}</ref> Poland regained some of the artefacts after the [[Peace of Riga|Treaty of Riga]], comprising the furnishings of the [[Royal Castle, Warsaw|Warsaw Castle]] and the [[Wawel Castle]].<ref>{{cite web |author = Pat MacAdam |url = http://stefanbatoryoceanliner.homestead.com/PolishTreasures.html |title = Evacuated Polish Royal Treasures onboard of M/S BATORY & the amazing story of keeping it safe in Canada, 1940–1961... |work = homestead.com |publisher = Ottawa Citizen columnist |date = April 10, 1999 |accessdate = 2008-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wawel.krakow.pl/en/index.php?op=4 |title = History of the Royal Residence |work = wawel.krakow.pl |accessdate = 2008-03-03}}</ref>
During the Second World War, Germany tried to destroy Poland completely and exterminate its population as well as culture. Countless art objects were looted, as Germany systematically carried out a plan of looting prepared even before the start of hostilities{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} (see also [[Nazi plunder]]).<ref name="MSZ"/> Twenty-five museums and many other facilities were destroyed.<ref name="MSZ"/> The total cost of German theft and destruction of Polish art is estimated at 20 billion dollars,<ref name="GW2007"/> or an estimated 43% of Polish cultural heritage; over 516,000 individual art pieces were looted (including 2,800 paintings by European painters; 11,000 paintings by Polish painters; 1,400 sculptures, 75,000 manuscripts, 25,000 maps, 90,000 books including over 20,000 printed before 1800, and hundreds of thousands of other items of artistic and historical value).<ref name="MSZ">{{pl icon}} [http://www.msz.gov.pl/Rewindykacja,dobr,kultury,1775.html Rewindykacja dóbr kultury] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070821215332/http://www.msz.gov.pl/Rewindykacja%2Cdobr%2Ckultury%2C1775.html |date=2007-08-21 }}</ref> Soviet troops afterward contributed to the plunder as well.<ref name="polamcon">{{cite web |url = http://www.polamcon.org/lostart/intro.htm |title = Wartime Losses-Polish Painting |work = polamcon.org |accessdate = 2008-03-03 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071218105004/http://www.polamcon.org/lostart/intro.htm |archivedate = December 18, 2007}}</ref>
===Looting of Latin and South America=== The looting of Central and South America by the [[conquistador]]s is one of the best-known plunders in the world.
Roger Atwood writes in ''Stealing History: Tomb Raiders, Smugglers, and the Looting of the Ancient World'': "Mayan stonework became one of those things that good art museums in America just had to have, and looters in the jungles of southern Mexico and Guatemala worked overtime to meet the demand."<ref name="auto1">Atwood, Roger. ''Stealing History: Tomb Raiders, Smugglers, and the Looting of the Ancient World''. St. Martin's Press. November 18, 2004</ref><ref name="auto2">Colin Woodard. [http://chronicle.com/free/v47/i08/08a02301.htm "Destructive Looting Threatens Archaeological Work at Maya Sites"]. ''[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]''. October 20, 2000</ref> <ref name="auto3">Jeremy McDermott. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/06/07/MN221710.DTL&type=science "Looting a lost civilization. Maya scholars in race with thieves"]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''. June 7, 2001</ref><ref name="auto4">Princine Lewis. [http://www.vanderbilt.edu/register/articles?id=12691 "Archaeologists partnership with Maya villagers pays off in looters' conviction"]. ''[[Vanderbilt Register]]''. June 23, 2004</ref> (See: [[Maya stelae#Looting]])
Looting in Mesoamerica has a long tradition and history. Graves are often looted before the archaeologists can reach them, and the artifacts are then sold to wealthy collectors in the United States, Japan, or Europe. Guillermo Cock, a Lima-based archaeologist, says about a recent find of dozens of exquisitely preserved Inca mummies on the outskirts of Peru's capital city, [[Lima]]: "The true problem is the looters," he said. "If we leave the cemetery it is going to be destroyed in a few weeks."<ref name="auto5">John Roach. [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2004/03/0311_040311_incamummies.html "Dozens of Inca Mummies Discovered Buried in Peru"]. ''[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]'' News, March 11, 2004</ref>
==Looting by perpetrator==
===Looting by the British Empire===
The transformation of theft and plunder as an incentive for troops to institutionalized, indiscriminate looting following military conflict can be observed in the wake of British conquest in Asia, Africa and India. The looting of artifacts for "both personal and institutional reasons" became "increasingly important in the process of "othering" Oriental and African societies and was exemplified in the professionalism of exploration and the growth of ethnographic departments in museums, the new 'temples of Empire'." Looting, not necessarily of art, became a vital instrument for the projection of power and the British imperial desire to gather and provide information about the "exotic" cultures and primitive tribes.<ref>Michael Carrington. Officers Gentlemen and Thieves: The Looting of Monasteries during the 1903/4. [[Francis Younghusband|Younghusband Mission]] to Tibet, [[Modern Asian Studies]] 37, 1 (2003), pp 81–109 {{doi|10.1017/S0026749X03001033}}</ref><ref>''Empire and authority: Curzon, collisions, character and the Raj, 1899–1905''. Michael Carrington. A Ph. D (British Library)</ref>
===Looting by Napoleon=== [[File:Descent from the Cross (Rembrant).jpg|thumb|[[Rembrandt]]'s ''Descent from the Cross'' was looted in 1806 by French soldiers from the [[Landgrave]] of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel|Hesse-Kassel]], Germany; current location: [[Hermitage Museum|Hermitage]], St. Petersburg.]]
Napoleon's conquests in Europe were followed by a systematic attempt, later more tentatively echoed by Hitler, to take the finest works of art of conquered nations back to the [[Louvre]] in Paris for a grand central museum of all Europe. Napoleon boasted: {{Centered pull quote|We will now have all that is beautiful in Italy except for a few objects in Turin and Naples.<ref name=time/>}} Many works were returned after his fall, but many others were not, and remain in France. Many works confiscated from religious institutions under the French occupation now form the backbone of national museums: "Napoleon's art-loot depots became the foundation of [[Gallerie dell'Accademia|Venice's Accademia]], Milan's [[Pinacoteca di Brera|Brera galleries]]. His brother [[Napoleon III of France|Louis]] founded [[Rijksmuseum Amsterdam|Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum]]; brother [[Joseph Bonaparte|Joseph]] started [[Museo del Prado|Madrid's Prado]]" (for the Spanish royal collection).<ref name=time>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,891933-1,00.html Masterpieces of the Louvre]. ''Time'' magazine. June 30, 1958</ref>
Napoleonic commander and Marechal [[Nicolas Jean-de-Dieu Soult]] stole in 1810 six large pictures painted by [[Bartolomé Esteban Murillo|Murillo]] in 1668 for the [[Hospital de la Caridad (Seville)|Hospital de la Caridad]] in [[Seville]]. One painting, ''[[The Return of the Prodigal Son]]'', is now in the [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington; a second looted painting, ''[[The Healing of the Paralytic]]'', is in the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] in London; only two of the original paintings have returned to Seville.<ref name=bloombergplease/>
Another French general looted several pictures, including four Claudes and [[Rembrandt]]'s ''[[Descent from the Cross]]'', from the [[Landgrave]] of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel|Hesse-Kassel]] in 1806. The stolen goods were later bought by the [[Joséphine de Beauharnais|Empress Josephine]] and subsequently by the tsar. Since 1918, when the [[Bolshevik]] government signed a peace treaty with Germany and Austria, have German negotiators demanded the return of the paintings. Russia refused to return the stolen goods; the pictures still remain in the Hermitage.<ref name=bloombergplease/>
===Looting by the Union and Confederate Armies during the American Civil War===
On November 7, 1863, [[Edward D. Townsend]] of the Union army wrote General Order No. 360: “Satisfactory evidence having been produced to the War Department that a bronze equestrian statue, unlawfully taken from a private house in Fredericksburg, at the time of the capture of that place by the Union forces, was the private property of Mr. Douglas Gordon, of that city, it is— .Ordered: That it be restored to Mrs. Annie C. Thomas, the sister of Mr. Gordon, who has made application therefor.”<ref>O'Brien, Thomas M., and Oliver Diefendorf. ''General Orders of the War Department, Embracing the Years 1861, 1862 & 1863''. Vol. 2. New York, NY: Derby & Miller, 1864, p. 603.</ref> Some of Gordon's works of art were recovered through [[Lafayette C. Baker]], chief of the Union secret police.<ref>Baker, Lafayette Curry. ''History of the United States Secret Service''. Philadelphia, PA: King & Baird, Printers, 1867, p. 259-260.</ref>
The United States Congress enacted legislation allowing for claims to be filed for property losses on July 4, 1864. Claims were restricted to loyal citizens.
===Looting by Nazi Germany=== {{main article|Nazi plunder|2012 Nazi loot discovery}} [[File:Eisenhower, Bradley and Patton inspect looted art HD-SN-99-02758.JPEG|right|thumb|General [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], Supreme Allied Commander, accompanied by General [[Omar N. Bradley]] and Lieutenant General [[George S. Patton]], Jr., inspects art treasures hidden in a salt mine in Germany.]]
During World War II, the Nazis set up special departments "for a limited time for the seizure and securing of objects of cultural value",<ref>[http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/proc/12-18-45.htm Letter from Rosenberg to the Reich Commissioner for the East and Reich Commissioner for the Ukraine, April 27, 1942], as cited in: Nuremberg Trial Proceedings Vol. 4. Twenty-Second Day. December 18, 1945, Morning Session, Document 153-PS, Exhibit USA-381</ref> especially in the Occupied Eastern Territories, including the [[Baltic states]], [[Ukraine]], [[Hungary]] and [[Greece]]. The Russian imperial residences around [[St. Petersburg]] were thoroughly looted and deliberately blown up, so that their restoration is still under way. The [[Catherine Palace]] and [[Peterhof Palace|Peterhof]] were reduced to smoldering ruins; among the innumerable trophies was the world-famous [[Amber Room]].<ref>Peter Bruhn: Das Bernsteinzimmer in Zarskoje Selo bei Sankt-Petersburg, 2nd edition. Berlin, 2004 {{ISBN|978-3-86155-109-6}}. In an updated version also available as bibliographical database [http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/bernzim.htm Das Bernsteinzimmer von Zarskoje Selo] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5msN0LHUv?url=http://www.ib.hu-berlin.de/~pbruhn/bernzim.htm |date=January 18, 2010 }}</ref> Medieval churches of [[Novgorod]] and [[Pskov]], with their unique 12th-century frescoes, were systematically plundered and reduced to piles of rubble. Major museums around [[Moscow]], including [[Yasnaya Polyana]], [[Joseph-Volokolamsk Monastery]], and [[New Jerusalem Monastery|New Jerusalem]], faced a similar fate, with their architectural integrity irrevocably impaired.
The legal framework and the language of the instructions used by Germany resembles the [[Lieber Code]], but in the [[Nuremberg Trial]] proceedings, the victorious Allied armies applied different standards and sentenced the Nazis involved as [[war criminals]]. Article 6 of the [[Charter of the International Military Tribunal]] of Nuremberg, detailing the Jurisdiction and General Principles, declares the "plunder of public or private property" a war crime,<ref>[http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/proc/imtconst.htm#art6 Nuremberg Trial Proceedings Vol. 1, Charter of the International Military Tribunal, II. Jurisdiction and General Principles, Article 6]. Yale.edu. Retrieved on 2011-06-12.</ref> while the Lieber Code and the actions of the Allied armies in the aftermath of World War II allowed or tolerated the looting. The main objective of the looting is made clear by Dr. Muhlmann, responsible for the securing of all Polish art treasures: "I confirm that the art treasures ... would not have remained in Poland in case of a German victory, but they would have been used to complement German artistic property."<ref name=nuremberg>[http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/proc/12-18-45.htm Nuremberg Trial Proceedings Vol. 4. Twenty-Second Day. December 18, 1945, Morning Session]. Yale.edu. Retrieved on 2011-06-12.</ref>
One inventory of 39 volumes featuring the looted art and antiques, prepared by the Nazis and discussed during the Nuremberg trials, lists "21,903 Works of Art: 5,281 paintings, pastels, water colors, drawings; 684 miniatures, glass and enamel paintings, illuminated books and manuscripts; 583 sculptures, terra cottas, medallions, and plaques; 2,477 articles of furniture of art historical value; 583 textiles (tapestries, rugs, embroideries, Coptic textiles); 5,825 objects of decorative art (porcelains, bronzes, [[faience]], [[Maiolica|majolica]], ceramics, jewelry, coins, art objects with precious stones); 1,286 East Asiatic art works (bronzes, sculpture, [[porcelain]]s, paintings, [[folding screen]]s, weapons); 259 art works of antiquity (sculptures, bronzes, vases, jewelry, bowls, [[engraved gem]]s, [[terracotta]]s)."<ref name=nuremberg/>
When Allied forces bombed Germany's cities and historic institutions, Germany "began storing the artworks in salt mines and caves for protection from Allied bombing raids. These mines and caves offered the appropriate humidity and temperature conditions for artworks."<ref>Anne Rothfeld. [https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2002/summer/nazi-looted-art-2.html?template=print Nazi Looted Art]. The U.S. National Archives and Records Administration. The Holocaust Records Preservation Project, Part 2. Fall 2002, Vol. 34, No. 3</ref> Much of this art was recovered by the Allied [[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program|Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives Section]] of the [[Office of Military Government, United States]], as detailed in a 1995 [[The Spoils of War (symposium)|conference in New York]] and the published proceedings.<ref>Simpson, Elizabeth. ''The Spoils of War--World War II and Its Aftermath: The Loss, Reappearance, and Recovery of Cultural Property''. New York: [[Abrams Books|Harry N. Abrams]] in association with the Bard Graduate Center, 1997.</ref>
===Looting by the Soviet Union=== [[File:Goldfund von Eberswalde.jpg|thumb|The [[Eberswalde Hoard]] from Germany disappeared in 1945 from Berlin and was located in 2004 in a secret depot within Moscow's [[Pushkin Museum]].]] The Soviet Union engaged in systematic looting during World War II, particularly of Germany – seeing this as reparations for damage and looting done by Germany in the Soviet Union.<ref name="ib.hu-berlin.de"/><ref>Lee, Steven. (2005-05-17) [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/16/world/europe/16iht-loot.html?_r=0 Cultural divide exists over Russian war loot]. ''The New York Times'', retrieved 2012-02-11</ref> The Soviets also looted other occupied territories; for example, looting by Soviets was common on the territories theoretically assigned to its ally, communist Poland.<ref name="Davies2">[[Norman Davies]], ''[[God's Playground]], a History of Poland'', Columbia University Press, 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-231-12819-3}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0231128193&id=EBpghdZeIwAC&pg=PA359 p.359]</ref><ref name="Raack">Richard C. Raack, ''Stalin's Drive to the West, 1938–1945: the origins of the Cold War'', Stanford University Press, 1995, {{ISBN|978-0-8047-2415-9}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0804724156&id=pAdZMaWn8cIC&pg=PA90 p.90]</ref> Even [[Polish Communists]] were uneasy, as in 1945, the future Chairman of the [[Polish Council of State]], [[Aleksander Zawadzki]], worried that the "raping and looting by the Soviet army would provoke a civil war."<ref name="Davies">[[Norman Davies]], ''[[God's Playground]], a History of Poland'', Columbia University Press, 1982, {{ISBN|978-0-231-05352-5}}, [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0231053525&id=DMoPXktGwiUC&pg=RA1-PA558 p.558]</ref> Soviet forces had engaged in plunder on the [[former eastern territories of Germany]] that were to be transferred to Poland, stripping it of anything of value.<ref name="IPN-MM">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321165047/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html |title=MIĘDZY MODERNIZACJĄ A MARNOTRAWSTWEM |archivedate=2005-03-21 |publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]] |language=Polish }} See also [http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm other copy online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426011453/http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm |date=2007-04-26 }}</ref><ref name="IPN-Ś">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/4/biuletyn4_51.html|title=ARMIA CZERWONA NA DOLNYM ŚLĄSKU|publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321233124/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/4/biuletyn4_51.html|archivedate=2005-03-21|language=Polish}}</ref> A recently recovered masterwork is [[Gustave Courbet]]'s ''[[Femme nue couchée]]'', looted in [[Budapest]], Hungary, in 1945.
In 1998, and after considerable controversy, Russia passed the [[Federal Law on Cultural Valuables Displaced to the USSR as a Result of the Second World War and Located on the Territory of the Russian Federation]], which allowed Russians to keep the illegally stolen art works and museum pieces and to prevent any restitution to their rightful owners in Germany.
===Looting by the Spanish Empire and others=== The [[conquistador]]s looting Latin and South America became one of the most commonly recognized plunders in the world.
Roger Atwood writes in ''Stealing History: Tomb Raiders, Smugglers, and the Looting of the Ancient World'': "Mayan stonework became one of those things that good art museums in America just had to have, and looters in the jungles of southern Mexico and Guatemala worked overtime to meet the demand."<ref name="auto1"/><ref name="auto2"/> <ref name="auto3"/><ref name="auto4"/> (See: [[Maya stelae#Looting]])
Looting in Mesoamerica has a long tradition and history, many graves are looted before the archaeologists could reach them, and the artifacts are then sold to wealthy collectors in the United States, Japan or Europe. [[Guillermo Cock]], a Lima-based archaeologist, says about a recent find of dozens of exquisitely preserved Inca mummies on the outskirts of Peru's capital city, [[Lima]]: "The true problem is the looters," he said. "If we leave the cemetery it is going to be destroyed in a few weeks."<ref name="auto5"/>
==Case studies== A large number of institutions and museums have at various times been subject to both moral claims and legal claims concerning the provenance of their holdings subject to occasional review and challenge. One example of such a case study can be provided by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]'s reputation which has experienced a series of allegations and lawsuits about its status as an occasional institutional buyer of looted and stolen antiquities. Since the 1990s the Met has been the subject of numerous investigative reports and books critical of the Met's ''laissez-faire'' attitude to acquisition.<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders>Peter Watson, Cecilia Todeschini (2007), [https://books.google.com/books?id=jlcPcCuicKQC&q=Morgantina%20Met%20OR%20Metropolitan ''The Medici Conspiracy: The Illicit Journey of Looted Antiquities from Italy's Tomb Raiders to the World's Greatest Museums'']</ref><ref>Vernon Silver, ''The Lost Chalice: The Epic Hunt for a Priceless Masterpiece''. Harper Collins Books, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-06-188296-8}}</ref> The Met has lost several major lawsuits, notably against the governments of Italy and Turkey, who successfully sought the repatriation of hundreds of ancient Mediterranean and Middle Eastern antiquities, with a total value in the hundreds of millions of dollars.<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders />
In the late 1990s, long-running investigations by the [[Carabinieri Art Squad|Tutela del Patrimonio Culturale]] (TPC), the art crimes division of the Italian [[Carabinieri]], accused the Metropolitan Museum of acquiring "black market" antiquities. TPC investigations in Italy revealed that many ancient Mediterranean objects acquired from the 1960s to the 1990s had been purchased, via a complex network of front companies and unscrupulous dealers, from the criminal gang led by Italian art dealer [[Giacomo Medici (art dealer)|Giacomo Medici]]."<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders /> The Met is also one of many institutional buyers known to have acquired looted artifacts from a Thai-based British "collector", [[Douglas Latchford]]."<ref>[http://chasingaphrodite.com/tag/metropolitan-museum-of-art/ Chasing Aphrodite]. "The Kushan Buddhas: Nancy Wiener, Douglas Latchford and New Questions about Ancient Buddhas" (originally posted 1 February 2015)</ref> In 2013, the Met announced that it would repatriate to [[Cambodia]] two ancient [[Khmer Republic|Khmer]] statues, known as "The Kneeling Attendants" , which it had acquired from Latchford (in fragments) in 1987 and 1992. A spokesperson for the Met stated that the museum had received "dispositive" evidence that the objects had been looted from Koh Ker and illegally exported to the USA.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-metropolitan-museum-returns-cambodian-statues-20130503-story.html Jason Felch, "Metropolitan Museum says it will return Cambodian statues"]. ''Los Angeles Times'', 3 May 2013</ref>
In addition to the ongoing investigations by the Italian police ([[Carabinieri Art Squad|TPC]]), lawsuits brought by the Governments of Italy, Turkey and Cambodia against the Metropolitan Museum of Art contend that the acquisition of the Euphronius krater may have demonstrated a pattern of less than rigorous investigation into the origin and legitimate provenance of highly desirable antiquities for the museum's collections. Examples include, the [[Cloisters Cross]], a large [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] cross carved from walrus ivory,<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders /> the [[Karun Treasure]], also known as the Lydian Hoard, a collection of 200 gold, silver, bronze and earthenware objects, dating from the 7th Century BCE, and part of a larger haul of some 450 objects looted by local tomb robbers from four ancient royal tombs near [[Sardis]], in Turkey in 1966–67.<ref>[http://www.thehistoryblog.com/archives/21761 "Gold hippocampus from Lydian Hoard found"]. The History Blog, 28 November 2012</ref> After a six-year legal battle that reportedly cost the Turkish government UK£25 million<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/nov/25/king-croesus-treasure-returning-turkey "King Croesus's golden brooch to be returned to Turkey"].Constanze Letch, ''The Guardian'', 26 November 2012</ref> the case ended dramatically after it was revealed that the minutes of the Met's own acquisition committee described how a curator had actually visited the looted burial mounds in Turkey to confirm the authenticity of the objects. The Met was forced to concede that staff had known the objects were stolen when it bought them, and the collection was repatriated to Turkey in 1993.<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders />
The [[Morgantina treasure]] is a hoard of ornate Hellenistic silverware dated 3rd century BC, valued at perhaps up to US$100 million, acquired by the Met in the early 1980s. It was later shown to have been looted from the [[Morgantina|Morgantina archaeological site]] in Sicily. After a protracted lawsuit, the Met conceded that it was looted, and agreed in 2006 to repatriate it to Sicily, with the Met stating in 2006 that the repatriation "redresses past improprieties in the acquisitions process".<ref name=IllicitTombRaiders /><ref>Article, [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/morgantina-silver/ "Morgantina Silver"], by Suzie Thomas, year 2012 at the website [http://traffickingculture.org/ TraffickingCulture.org], website devoted to illicit trafficking in ancient art objects. The article cites the following press release issued by the Metropolitian Museum on 21 Feb 2006: [http://www.metmuseum.org/press/news/2006/statement-by-the-metropolitan-museum-of-art-on-its-agreement-with-italian-ministry-of-culture "Statement by the Metropolitan Museum of Art on its agreement with the Italian Ministry of Culture"].</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Antiquities trade]] * [[Art theft]] * [[Art theft and looting during World War II]] * [[Interpol]] * [[List of artworks with contested provenance]] * [[Royal Casket]] * [[Polish Crown Jewels]] * [[War loot]] * [[List of missing treasure]] * [[United States restitution to the Soviet Union]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== {{refbegin|30em}} * O'Connor, Anne-Marie (2012). The Lady in Gold, The Extraordinary Tale of Gustav Klimt's Masterpiece, Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer, Alfred A. Knopf, New York, {{ISBN|0-307-26564-1}}. * {{cite book|last=Akinsha|first=Konstantin|title=Beautiful Loot: The Soviet Plunder of Europe's Art Treasures|year=1995|publisher=Random House|location=New York}} * {{cite book|last=Alford|first=Kenneth|title=The Spoils of World War II: The American Military's Role in the Stealing of Europe's Treasures|year=1994|publisher=Carol Publishing Group|location=New York}} * {{cite book|last=Atwood|first=Roger|title=Stealing History: Tomb Raiders, Smugglers, and the Looting of the Ancient World|publisher=St. Martin's Press|date=November 18, 2004}} * {{cite journal|last=Carrington|first=Michael|title=Officers Gentlemen and Thieves: The Looting of Monasteries during the 1903/4 Younghusband Mission to Tibet|journal=Modern Asian Studies|year=2003|volume=37|issue=1|pages=81–109|publisher=Cambridge University Press|doi=10.1017/s0026749x03001033}} * {{cite book|last=Chamberlin|first=E. R.|title=Loot!: The Heritage of Plunder|year=1983|publisher=Facts on File|location=New York}} * {{cite book|last=De Jaeger|first=Charles|title=The Linz File: Hitler's Plunder of Europe's Art|year=1981|publisher=Webb & Bower|location=Exeter, England}} * {{cite book|last=Feliciano|first=Hector|title=The Lost Museum: The Nazi Conspiracy to Steal the World's Greatest Works of Art|year=1997|publisher=BasicBooks|location=New York}} * {{cite book|last=Pork|first=Milbry|title=The Looting of the Iraq Museum, Baghdad: The Lost Legacy of Ancient Mesopotamia|publisher=Harry N. Abrams|author2=Angela M.H. Schuster |date=May 1, 2005}} {{refend}}
==External links== {{commons category|Looting}} * [http://lsh.it-norr.com/default.asp?id=3032&refid=0 ''War-booty'' exhibition at Livrustkammaren, Stockholm, 22 November, 2007–28 February, 2009 (In English)] * [http://www.lootedartcommission.com/ Commission for Looted Art in Europe] * [[Koordinierungsstelle für Kulturgutverluste|Lost Art Database]] [http://www.lostart.de/Webs/EN/Start/Index.html Koordinierungsstelle für Kulturgutverluste, Magdeburg, Germany (In English)] * [http://roofkunst.com/en Looted Art in the Netherlands/Roofkunst voor, tijdens en na WO II]

The '''Division of Ecological Restoration''' (DER) is a Division of the Massachusetts Department of Fish and Game within the [[Massachusetts Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs|Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs]]. DER was created in 2009 with the merger of the Riverways and Wetlands Restoration Programs. DER coordinates ecological restoration to improve ecological condition and to restore important [[ecosystem services]] that improve the quality of life for all Massachusetts citizens.
The Riverways Program ([https://malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleII/Chapter21a MGL Chapter 21A Section 8]) has been maintained within DER and coordinates outreach and technical assistance to support [[drainage divide|watershed]] conservation and protection.
The Division and partners facilitate capital-based projects including (but not limited to) dam removal and [[culvert]] replacement with the goal of restoring [[aquatic habitat]]s (e.g. salt marshes) and ecosystems across the state. These projects support commercial and recreational fisheries and provide many other benefits such as reduced flooding, improved water quality, [[carbon sequestration]] and increased public safety.
Ecological restoration is a core component of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts efforts to build habitat resiliency to better allow fish and wildlife to adapt to climate change – including sea level rise, elevated water temperatures, and increased floods and periods of drought.
[[File:Logo Tagline MADFG.jpg|thumbnail|Division of Ecological Restoration seal]]
Tim Purinton currently serves as the Director of the Division of Ecological Restoration.
==Philosophy== *DER espouses a comprehensive, holistic approach to restoration, that prioritizes ecosystems over habitats. *DER places an emphasis on restoring ecological processes, rather than species specific habitats, focusing on implementation of restoration actions at a watershed scale. *DER staff identifies the most detrimental stressors in the larger watershed context and coordinates restoration actions to improve conditions in partnership with local organizations. *DER bases its programs on engaging and working with stakeholders in the communities to maximize impact and stewardship.
==External links== *[http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dfg/der/ Mass Division of Ecological Restoration] *[http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dfg/ Mass Department of Fish and Game] *[http://www.ser.org/ Society for Ecological Restoration]

{{Infobox organization | name = Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History | image = Max-Planck-Institut Jena 2014.jpg | size = | alt = | caption = The old building at the MPI for Economics in [[Jena]] | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | abbreviation = SHH | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date and age|1993}} | extinction = | type = Scientific institute | status = | purpose = Research in [[archaeogenetics]], [[evolutionary linguistics]] and [[archaeology]] | headquarters = [[Jena]], [[Germany]] | location = | coords = | region_served = | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = | leader_name = | key_people = Johannes Krause (co-founder)
Russell Gray (co-founder) Nicole Boivin | main_organ = | parent_organization = [[Max Planck Society]] | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = [http://www.shh.mpg.de/en {{en icon}}]
[http://www.shh.mpg.de/ {{de icon}}] | remarks = | former name = Max Planck Institute for Research into Economic Systems
Max Planck Institute for Economics }} The '''Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History''' ([[German language|German]]: ''Max-Planck-Institut für Menschheitsgeschichte'') performs basic research into [[archaeogenetics]] and [[Evolutionary linguistics|linguistic cultural evolution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.shh.mpg.de/en|title=Institute Profile|publisher=MPI-SHH|accessdate=2015-04-05}} The institute is one of 80+ research institutes of the [[Max Planck Society]] and is located in [[Jena]], [[Germany]]. The co-directors of the institute are: * [[Nicole Boivin]] (Department of Archaeology) see [https://www.shh.mpg.de/archaeology Homepage of the departement of archaeology] * [[Russell Gray]] (Department of Linguistic and Cultural Evolution) * [[Johannes Krause]] (Department of Archeogenetics) == History == === Max Planck Institute of Economics === The predecessor of the present institute was founded in 1993 as the [[Max Planck Institute for Research into Economic Systems]] (''Max-Planck-Institut zur Erforschung von Wirtschaftssystemen'') and later renamed the [[Max Planck Institute of Economics]] (''Max-Planck-Institut für Ökonomik''). Its initial mission was researching the transition of the former [[Eastern Europe|Eastern European]] [[socialism|socialist]] economic systems, but it later researched a broad set of problems relating to change in modern economies more generally, including [[evolutionary economics]], [[experimental economics]], and [[entrepreneurial studies]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.econ.mpg.de/english/institute/|title=About the Max Planck Institute of Economics|accessdate=15 April 2015}} It was organized into three research units: * Evolutionary Economics Group (director: [[Ulrich Witt]]), * Strategic Interaction Group (director: [[Werner Güth]]) * Entrepreneurship, Growth and Public Policy Group (director: [[David B. Audretsch]]). ===Present-day=== On March 2014, the institute was renamed the Max Planck Institute for History and the Sciences. A few months later, on November 21, 2014, the Institute of Economics was realigned and renamed to the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History.{{cite web|url=http://www.mpg.de/8281472/Institute_in_Jena_realigned|title=Institute in Jena realigned|date=June 26, 2014|accessdate=2015-04-05|publisher=Max Planck Society}} In 2015 it took over from the [[Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology]] the task of maintaining the [[Glottolog]]. == Location == The institute is located on Kahlaische Strasse, about 1 km south-east of the city center. It is housed in an attractively restored [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] villa, linked by a glass bridge to a much larger modern building, which includes offices and other facilities for each of the research units, each unit having one floor of the main section of the building. In addition the new buildings include a substantial library, and apartments where visitors to the institute can be accommodated. ==References== ==External links== *{{en icon}} [http://www.shh.mpg.de/en Website for the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History] *{{en icon}} [http://www.econ.mpg.de/english/ Website for the former Max Planck Institute of Economics] {{coord|50|55|3|N|11|34|41|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Max Planck Society}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Max Planck Institutes|Science of Human History]] [[Category:Research institutes established in 1993]] [[Category:Anthropological research institutes]] [[Category:Genetics or genomics research institutions]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Jena]] {{Germany-university-stub}} {{science-org-stub}}
